title: How to send a password securely
excerpt: Stop sending credentials in chat apps. Use one-time secrets with expiry and view limits.

content.text: Sending passwords in chat apps feels fast. It is also a reliable way to leak credentials through screenshots, message exports, sync backups, notification previews, or “just forward this to Bob.” Encryption helps in transit. It does not fix what happens after delivery.

content.title: Rule #1
content.text: If it can be copied and reshared, assume it will be.
Why chat is the wrong container

Chat is optimized for persistence and search. That is the opposite of what you want for secrets. Even if you delete a message, retention policies or device backups can keep it alive. Even if your team is careful, one rushed moment creates a permanent artifact.

items: Admins can export logs (even in ‘secure’ tools)
Notifications leak previews to lock screens
Recipients can copy, forward, screenshot, or paste into notes
Shared devices and cloud backups keep history

content.text: A secure workflow that stays fast
The goal is not perfect security. The goal is reduced blast radius with a process humans can actually follow at 2 AM.

items: Put the password/token into a one-time secret
Set expiry based on risk (15–60 minutes is a good default)
Optionally add a passphrase for high-risk secrets
Send the link in your normal channel
If you used a passphrase, send it via a different channel

content.text: Choosing expiry time without overthinking

items: Emergency access: shortest possible, rotate afterwards

content.text: Passphrases: the split-channel rule
A passphrase only adds security if it is shared separately. Link in Signal, passphrase by phone. Link in email, passphrase in chat. Split the risk so a single leak doesn’t unwrap everything.

content.title: Common mistake
content.text: Sending the passphrase in the same message as the link. That’s not security, it’s decoration.
After the secret is used

If the credential grants ongoing access, plan rotation. The safest practice is to treat ‘shared’ as ‘temporary’ and rotate after the task finishes. This turns leaks into inconveniences instead of incidents.
Security that depends on people behaving perfectly is not security.

title: Stop pasting API keys into Slack
excerpt: Slack is for coordination. It is not a vault. Here’s a workflow that doesn’t melt productivity.

content.text: Slack and Teams are amazing at moving information quickly. They are also amazing at keeping information forever. The moment an API key enters chat, you have created a durable, searchable credential archive.
Why API keys in chat are a real incident

items: Search makes old keys easy to rediscover
Retention and exports keep copies even after deletion
Bots and integrations can accidentally capture secrets
Screen notifications expose content on lock screens
Forwarding spreads secrets to new audiences

content.title: Simple policy
content.text: If a key touched chat, treat it as compromised and rotate it.
The safe workflow for keys

items: Scope it to the minimum permissions
Store the key in your secret manager
Share the key via a one-time secret link (view-once + expiry)
Rotate again after the task if the key was temporary

content.text: Make rotation boring
If rotation is scary, the system is fragile. Build the habit: separate keys per environment, clear owners, automated deprovision. Then rotation becomes a routine maintenance task, not a crisis.
Practical defaults

items: Prod keys: expiry 10–15 minutes, view-once + passphrase

content.text: How to message it to the team
Don’t shame people for pasting keys. Replace the habit with a faster alternative. The secure path should be one click, not a lecture.
Users do what’s easiest. Make safe easy.

title: One-time links vs encrypted chat: what’s safer?
excerpt: Encryption protects delivery. View limits and expiry control exposure after delivery.

content.text: “Just use encrypted chat” is a common answer to secret sharing. Encryption is important. But most leaks happen after the message is delivered: screenshots, forwards, backups, exports, and compromised devices.
What encrypted chat does well

items: Prevents casual eavesdropping by ISPs and Wi‑Fi hotspots

content.text: What encrypted chat does not solve

items: Admins can export logs in many org setups
Devices can be compromised after decryption

content.text: What one-time secrets add
One-time links reduce the blast radius of mistakes by limiting replay. Forwarded links become useless after first view or after expiry. It’s not magic. It is damage control.
Best practice combination

items: Use one-time secrets for actual secrets
Use passphrase + split channel for high-risk data
Rotate credentials after use when possible

content.title: Threat model note
content.text: If the recipient’s device is compromised, nothing saves you. The goal is to avoid accidental, low-effort leaks.
Crypto protects transit. Workflow protects reality.

content.text: Send secrets as secrets, not as messages.

title: Secure sharing for teams without slowing down

title: Password reset links are secrets too

content.text: A password reset link is a temporary master key. If someone else gets it first, they reset the password and own the account. That is not theoretical. It happens constantly.

Safer support workflow

Verify identity before any reset steps
Encourage immediate use then invalidate/rotate if unsure

content.text: Never ask a user to send you their password or 2FA codes. Ever.

title: Expiry time guide: choosing TTL without guessing
excerpt: Pick TTL based on risk and workflow. Stop defaulting to ‘forever’.

content.text: Expiry is your damage control knob. Too long and secrets linger like bad decisions. Too short and humans fail the process and paste it into chat anyway.
A practical TTL ladder
View limits matter more than TTL
TTL controls time. View-once controls replay. In most cases, view-once + reasonable TTL beats long TTL without view limits.

content.title: Good default
content.text: Expiry 60 minutes + view-once. Adjust down for prod.

title: Screenshots are the unpatchable vulnerability
excerpt: Most leaks happen after decryption. Screenshots, photos, copy-paste.

content.text: Security tools love to talk about encryption. Attackers love screenshots. The easiest data theft is the kind that bypasses crypto entirely: capture what’s on the screen and share it.
Why screenshots are dangerous

items: They survive deletion of the original message
They can be reshared without context
They can be taken by cameras, not just OS screenshot tools

content.text: What you can do anyway
You can’t stop screenshots in general. You can reduce the value of what gets captured.

items: Avoid displaying the secret in meetings/screenshares
Split link and passphrase for high-risk secrets

content.text: UI habit
When sharing a secret, prefer ‘copy’ to clipboard over rendering the full value on screen for long periods. Less exposure time, less risk.
If you can see it, you can steal it.

content.title: Reduce screenshot damage
content.text: Use one-time secrets so leaked screenshots expire quickly.

content.text: Use a guest network when possible

title: Why view-once matters more than encryption (sometimes)
excerpt: Encryption protects transit. View-once protects you from replay, forwarding, and retention.

content.text: Encryption is necessary. It is not sufficient. Many leaks happen after the recipient has the plaintext: forwarding, screenshots, exports, backups, and device compromise.
View-once reduces replay
If a secret can be replayed, it can be reshared. View-once changes the economics: a forwarded link is often useless because the secret is already consumed.
Where view-once is essential
Combine with rotation
The strongest pattern is view-once + short TTL + rotation after use for high impact access. This turns accidental leaks into time-limited noise.

content.title: Quick rule
content.text: If it would hurt to leak tomorrow, it shouldn’t still exist tomorrow.
